statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Purdue 90, Northern Colorado 58
article.story: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. (AP) -- Purdue was an outmanned, overachieving bunch last season that struggled to compete on a nightly basis. In Monday's season opener, the Boilermakers unveiled a running, pressing, dunking, sharpshooting machine. Purdue scored its highest point total in four years in a 90-58 win over Northern Colorado. "They're tremendously athletic," Northern Colorado coach Tad Boyle said. "They have tremendous size on the perimeter. And they shot the ball well." Purdue didn't resemble the slow-paced team that lacked depth in a 9-19 campaign because none of Monday's starters played more than five games last season. Carl Landry and David Teague came back from season-ending knee injuries, Gordon Watt is a transfer who sat out last season, Tarrance Crump was suspended last season and Chris Kramer is a freshman. Landry scored 18 points and Teague added 13. Reserves Keaton Grant and Chris Lutz each scored 12 points and Watt had 10 points and nine rebounds for the Boilermakers. Purdue coach Matt Painter said he has so many good players that he's struggling to figure out how to use them. "Sometimes, you have five starters," he said. "Last year, we had two or three starters, and you've got to start five. Sometimes you have nine. If you've got eight or nine starters ... right now, I've got a good problem." Sean Taibi led Northern Colorado (0-2) with 19 points and Kirk Archibeque added 15. Purdue (1-0) shot 11-for-25 from 3-point range and forced 33 turnovers. It was the Boilermakers' highest point total since a 95-65 win over San Diego in December 2002. Landry tore a ligament in his right knee late in the 2004-2005 season and had offseason surgery. He played five games last season before lingering pain led him to a medical redshirt. He left Monday's game with 6:15 left and Purdue holding a 71-43 lead. It was Teague's first regular-season game since the end of the 2004-2005 season. He missed last season after tearing a ligament in his left knee just before the opener. Watt is a transfer from Boston College. He gave the Boilermakers what they expected from him in his debut. "It's very rare on the basketball court that you can find somebody who matches your intensity level," Teague said. "Every day in practice and in the game, he gets guys going. He's a great motivator and defender." Purdue led 20-10 before Lutz made two 3-pointers in an 8-0 run that gave the Boilermakers a 28-10 advantage and forced a Northern Colorado timeout. Northern Colorado cut Purdue's advantage to 33-25 late in the first half, but a dunk by Landry, a steal and layup by Kramer and two free throws by Kramer with 1.9 seconds left in the first half gave the Boilermakers a 39-27 lead at the break. Purdue started the second half with eight quick points to take a 47-27 lead with 18:47 left. After a Northern Colorado timeout, the Boilermakers scored seven more points before the Bears finally scored to end the 15-0 run. Northern Colorado scored its first basket of the second half with 15:08 left. Painter told his team it needed to make up for missed opportunities to pull away in the first half. "We knew we had to jump on them right away and put that pressure on them and try to force them into some turnovers, and we were able to do that," Painter said. Boyle said Purdue still plays with the same intensity as last year's squad. "Coaches talk about their teams playing hard," Boyle said, "but Matt's teams actually do."
